comments:
Hello,

I've been having lots of problems with Eclipse's CVS support for a few releases now.  I commonly get errors during checkouts or updates.  Up until now, I've always been able to find workarounds that got me what I needed.  However, I am now in a situation where I can no longer use the team features of Eclipse.

The Problem:
The product line on which I work has a very large code base, and at times has some very large files and files encoded in a variety of charsets (i.e. SJIS, etc.).  While attempting to checkout a module from the CVS Repository view, I ran into a situation where the checkout fails with the error included below.  The module is partially checked out, so I was able to start to update the module.  Updating the module also fails for the same reason (buffer overflow).  At this point, I can no longer retrieve the rest of the module.

I searched for various elements of the stack trace in both Eclipse's and Sun's bug system and have come to the conclusion that this is most likely a problem in the JDK.  Sun bug#s 5053096, 4997240 and 5056440 are the issues I thought most closely match the error.  Despite claims that they have fixed this, the latest JDK, 1.5.0_08 did not resolve the issue.

If my suspicion is correct and this is a problem where the Eclipse CVS code is failing because the file is huge and the JDK has one of these silly 64K limitations, then it seems that the Eclipse CVS client (or more generally any Eclipse use of character streams) should guard against this.

Thanks in advance for your good work, and accept my apologies for the long-winded bug report.

--- Contents of error log follow ---

eclipse.buildId=M20060629-1905
java.version=1.5.0_08
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments:  -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86

I placed the wrong error log entry in the bug report.  The one in the original entry is the error that occurred when I tried to sync the module.  The same stack trace occurred during subsequent updates.  The error encountered while checking out the module follows.

I've looked at the code and it would appear that the invalid value that is causing the exception is a class constant of a JDK class. If you use an older JDK (e.g. a 1.4) do you get the errors? Could you reobtain your 1.5 VM and reinstall to see if that fixes the problem.

I tried again, this time using JDK v.1.4.2_12.  The module checkout failed once again, but this time for different reasons.  This failure appears to be caused by the same buffer overflow problem associated with the update/synch I posted earlier.

All I can tell you is that the code is question is just creating a string from a set of bytes using the platform's default encoding. What is your default encoding for Java (not Eclipse)? If you set it to something else, does it work?

Created an attachment (id=48648)
Eclipse configuration details

I uploaded the configuration details in case you find that you might need infor contained therein.

I've made further findings in this regard.

I went ahead and checked out the module using a command-line cvs client and then shared the resulting project in Eclipse.  As this isn't a seamless process (many files are considered locally modified), I have to sync the project with the repository to get the local workspace in the correct state.

The module still cannot be synchronized or updated, as both these operations fail as before (Buffer Overflow).  However, if I manually select smaller subsets of module (i.e. several folders at a time) and synchronize them, I am able to work around this problem.  

Is the size of one of the strings being manipulated by the CVS code dependent on the number of files being updated/synchronized?

Note that the modules in question are very large collections of folders, each nested fairly deeply.  We're talking about many thousands of files and folders, nested 5 - 10 levels deep.
No, the length of the strings in the CSV meta data do not depend on the size of files. Can you increase the memory and see if that helps (e.g. -Xmx512M)?

Increasing memory does not solve the problem.  I continue to have to select a few folders at a time to sync/update or else run into the BufferOverflow.

We are running an older version of CVS server.  I suspect this is part of the reason I have other problems, like incompatibilities in the /CVS/Entries files between sources managed via CVS client and Eclipse CVS.  Do you think this is contributing to the problem?  What I don't understand is why I'm having these problems now, and I didn't have these problems with earlier versions of Eclipse.  I also don't understand why problems with memory or CVS versions would manifest themselves as BufferOverflow exceptions.

Here's my CVS version info:
>cvs version
Client: Concurrent Versions System (CVS) 1.11.5 (client)
Server: Concurrent Versions System (CVS) 1.11 (client/server)

You are correct. You are using an unsupported server version. I can't see how this would cause the problems you are seeing but I guess it is possible. Would it be possible for you to upgrade your server to a supported version (1.11.1p1 or later) and try again? It is my understanding that 1.11 has some security holes in it but this would not be an issue if your server is internal.

I have made an interesting discovery.  One of my colleagues noted that he had not had any of the problems that I have experienced.  The only discernable difference was the version of Eclipse being used.  I decided to try this and found that none of the problems I have documented in this log occurr using the following version of Eclipse.
  Version: 3.1.2
  Build id: M20060118-1600

Note that all other aspects remain the same.  Workspace, JVM and CVS version.

Has your collegue tried 3.2 and experienced the problems you described? The reason I ask is that we have a lot of users and no one else has reported this problem. The other thing to consider is that 1.11 is unsupported. For us to even consider looking at this, we would need to have the problem occur on a supported version of CVS and we would need to have a scenario that reproduced the problem (i.e. if we can't reproduce it, we can't fix it). Please reopen if you upgrade to a supported version of CVs and still experience the problem.
There is a possibility that this is related to bug 92250. You may want to try increasing your permgen memory to see if that helps.
